verses.text: Do not envy evil men, nor desire to be with them,
verses.comment: The caution against envying the wicked echoes Psalm 37:1 and earlier Proverbs. The underlying spiritual message is a call to pursue righteousness, not worldly gain.

verses.text: for their hearts plot violence, and their lips speak trouble.
verses.comment: Evil associates corrupt with their intentions and speech. Scripture connects heart and mouth—what fills the heart overflows through the lips (cf. Luke 6:45).

verses.text: By wisdom a house is built, and by understanding it is established;
verses.comment: Building a house symbolizes constructing a life or family. Spiritual wisdom, not merely human knowledge, is the foundation (cf. Matthew 7:24—Christ as wise builder).

verses.text: with knowledge its rooms are filled with all precious and pleasant riches.
verses.comment: True wealth is found in the treasures of virtue and faith, more lasting than material riches. Symbolically, drawing near to the mysteries of the faith fills our lives.

verses.text: A wise man is strong, and a person of knowledge increases power.
verses.comment: Spiritual strength comes from wisdom and right understanding. This hints at the necessity of ongoing growth in the knowledge of God, often fostered within the community of believers.

verses.text: For by wise guidance you wage your war, and victory comes with many counselors.
verses.comment: The value of advice from many points to the unity and guidance of the community in discernment, reflecting early traditions of apostolic counsel and authority.

verses.text: Wisdom is too high for a fool; he does not open his mouth in the gate.
verses.comment: The gate was the place of judgment and public discourse. The fool is excluded from meaningful participation, pointing to the need for humble seeking of truth.

verses.text: Whoever plans to do evil will be called a schemer.
verses.comment: God knows the motives of the heart. Inward corruption is condemned, highlighting the need for inner transformation.

verses.text: The devising of folly is sin, and the scoffer is detested by men.
verses.comment: Sin begins in the intention. Contrast with the blessed who walk in wisdom and fear of the Lord (cf. Psalm 1).

verses.text: If you faint in the day of adversity, your strength is small.
verses.comment: Adversity tests character and faith. This resonates with New Testament teaching on perseverance under trial (cf. James 1:2-4), and spiritual fortitude cultivated in enduring the cross.

verses.text: Rescue those being taken away to death; hold back those stumbling toward the slaughter.
verses.comment: A call for active charity and defense of the vulnerable, prefiguring Christ's sacrificial rescue of all in danger of spiritual death.

verses.text: If you say, 'See, we did not know this,' does not He who weighs the heart perceive it? And does not He who guards your soul know, and will He not repay each one according to his works?
verses.comment: There is personal responsibility before God. Divine justice factor in knowledge and deeds (cf. Romans 2:6; Revelation 22:12), a theme flowing through the whole Scriptural witness.

verses.text: My son, eat honey, for it is good, and the honeycomb is sweet to your taste.
verses.comment: Honey represents the sweetness of wisdom and of God's law (cf. Psalm 19:10). Spiritual nourishment is both delightful and life-giving.

verses.text: So you should know wisdom for yourself. If you find it, then there will be a future, and your hope will not be cut off.
verses.comment: Finding wisdom ensures a lasting hope. This spiritual promise points to the fulfillment found in union with Christ, who is wisdom itself (cf. 1 Cor. 1:24).

verses.text: Do not lie in wait, wicked man, against the dwelling of the righteous; do not plunder his home.
verses.comment: The righteous are under divine protection. This foreshadows Christ, persecuted for righteousness but ultimately victorious.

verses.text: For the righteous may fall seven times and rise again, but the wicked stumble in calamity.
verses.comment: Seven implies completeness; repeated falls with restoration point to the grace that sustains the faithful, reflecting Christ's ministry of forgiveness and renewal.

verses.text: Do not rejoice when your enemy falls, and do not let your heart be glad when he stumbles;
verses.comment: Christ commands love for enemies (Matt. 5:44), transcending natural wisdom. This verse anticipates the perfection of mercy fulfilled in the Gospel.

verses.text: lest the LORD see it, and it displeases Him, and He turns His anger away from him.
verses.comment: God’s grace extends even to the fallen, a gentle reminder to avoid pride and vengeance. Divine justice is perfect and restorative.

verses.text: Do not fret because of evildoers, nor be envious of the wicked,
verses.comment: The recurring warning against envy and anxiety about sinners underscores trust in divine providence, a virtue cultivated by deep spiritual practice.

verses.text: for the evil man has no future; the lamp of the wicked will be put out.
verses.comment: The end of the wicked is darkness, a metaphor for separation from God—countered by Christ’s promise of eternal life and light for the faithful.

verses.text: My son, fear the LORD and the king, and do not join with those who seek change;
verses.comment: Respect for divine and earthly authority is commanded; this principle supports traditions of obedience and hierarchy in the faith community.

verses.text: for their disaster will arise suddenly, and who knows the ruin that will come from both?
verses.comment: Rebellion leads to ruin. The verse warns against resisting legitimate authority, a lesson echoed throughout Scripture for holy order.

verses.text: These also are sayings of the wise: To show partiality in judgment is not good.
verses.comment: Righteous judgment is impartial. This connects to the Church’s insistence on just discernment and equality before God’s law.

verses.text: Whoever says to the wicked, 'You are righteous,' peoples will curse him, nations will abhor him;
verses.comment: Twisting truth undermines justice, a warning not to compromise God's standards.

verses.text: but those who rebuke the wicked have delight, and a good blessing comes upon them.
verses.comment: Just rebuke brings blessing, encouraging Christians to uphold truth in charity, aligning with the call to admonish one another in love (cf. Col. 3:16).

verses.text: An honest answer is like a kiss on the lips.
verses.comment: Honest speech fosters true spiritual communion, echoing the intimate bond and trust shared in Christian fellowship.

verses.text: Prepare your work outside, and make it ready for yourself in the field; afterward build your house.
verses.comment: Order and prudence in work and life are vital—a spiritual reminder to establish one’s soul before outward building.

verses.text: Do not be a witness against your neighbor without cause, and do not deceive with your lips.
verses.comment: This command reflects the moral law forbidding false witness—a foundation for community and justice in Scripture and tradition.

verses.text: Do not say, 'I will do to him as he has done to me; I will repay the man according to his work.'
verses.comment: Repaying evil for evil is forbidden; the call is to forgive and leave vengeance to God (cf. Romans 12:17), a core theme in Christian spiritual formation.

verses.text: I passed by the field of a sluggard, by the vineyard of one lacking sense,
verses.comment: The imagery of field and vineyard recalls the labor entrusted to us in God’s kingdom—the vineyard often representing the people of God (cf. Isa. 5:1-7).

verses.text: and behold, it was all overgrown with thorns; its surface was covered with nettles, and its stone wall was broken down.
verses.comment: Neglect leads to spiritual ruin. The breakdown of a wall symbolically represents losing spiritual safeguards, anticipating Christ’s warning against the neglect of grace.

verses.text: Then I looked and considered it; I saw and received instruction.
verses.comment: Wisdom comes by observing life and spiritual realities, a hallmark of biblical meditation.

verses.text: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to rest,
verses.comment: Repeated sloth is dangerous spiritually and materially, reminiscent of admonitions to spiritual vigilance in the Gospels (cf. Matt. 25:13).

verses.text: then poverty will come upon you like a robber, and want like an armed man.
verses.comment: Spiritual and material poverty result from neglect and idleness, echoing Christ’s parables urging preparedness for His coming (cf. Luke 12:35-40).
